title: Let's make some use of this Modding forum.
content:
Alright, we've already got K:M which is a great place to go and discuss patches, patch requests, mod debuts, previous mods, and modding theory (as in, how to use color, good shading tricks, etc.) ... What's this place got to offer?

Simple: the people who read the modding section of this forum aren't specialists. Think about that for a moment--they're the people who are interested in Keen enough to have a passing interest in the fangames and mods that exist, but they're either not technical enough or not interested in the behind-the-scenes stuff enough to go visit K:M.

This is an excellent place to discuss what the un-modding public would like to see in their mods, or to gather input on what players would like to see.

So let's get some discussion, or at least some posts, from those of you who never venture over to adurdin's realm: What do you want to see in a mod? What seperates a mod from a fangame, to you? Why do you prefer one over the other? What can mods do to attract your attention?

K:M regulars, feel free to jump in with feedback and such, but I'm mainly interested in the posters who don't frequent K:M.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/posted-pics/XkyRauhKeenLogo.png[/img]

title: *sigh*
content:
This topic was posted 6 days ago, and it's received zero replies thus far.

To those of you arguing that the PCKF needs/needed a Modding section, I'm disappointed that you wouldn't participate in a simple opinion-based survey to help establish this new branch.

To those of you who argued that the PCKF is/was better off without a Modding section, I'm inclined to agree. The [url=http://andy.durdin.net/keen/modding/viewtopic.php?t=851]mirror topic[/url] to this thread over at K:M had a handful of replies in less than 24 hours.

Where are the non-K:M'ers?

* Why do you prefer one over the other?
* What can mods do to attract your attention? [hr][/quote]
Start by reading the first post, Naj. I edited it a bit, so it's more straightforward.

I want the non-modders to discuss modding, from an idealist, non-technical perspective. Whenever I hop into the FanGames forum, everything I say is theory; I don't make FanGames, I don't use GameMaker, I don't code, and I rarely play them. I view FanGames from a completely outside perspective--but I still contribute to their threads, in hopes a FanGame is made that can catch my interest.

This thread is an invitation to FanGamers to reciprocate.

- The fact that it's Keen, and not someone elses idea of how keen shall move
- I know the controls
- A lot
* Why do you prefer one over the other?
- Keens graphics aren't disappoining, because I know its limits: fangames have true color at their fingertips; to not use it would be to waste a lot of potential. Plus, you can do anything with a fangame, and so it better be great, and very Keenish, or its some cheep freeware that happens to star Keen

* What can mods do to attract your attention? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
- Use Keen 4, 5, 6
- Graphics: Keen 4, 5, and 6 used only 16 colors, like the origionals, but the colors were used in a way that one would have the illusion of more colors: mods, you have a reputation to live up to; large areas of one color bore me, at least checker it...Tough Guys Wear Pink!!!

title: Re: yay
content:
One thing that would get my attention is a storyline (and characters, levels, etc.) that tie in to the previous Keen games. Most mods (and fangames) seem to be completely separate from the existing games (sort of like how the only thing linking Invasion of the Vorticons and Goodbye Galaxy is Keen himself.)

I would really like to see a mod/fangame revisit the old places Keen has been been before, only set many years after the original games. It would be interesting to find out what has happened to all the places and characters we know from the old games. Sort of like "where are they now?" Are the places on Gnosticus IV still bustling with locals? Have they made changes to their towns and buildings, or have they abandoned some and let them fall to ruin? A mod like this would be interesting because it should have entirely new graphics, but most of them would remind you of the original Keen games, thus providing the link back to the real Keen universe.

Or perhaps the Shikadi have become very angry with Keen for destroying their plans in Keen 5, and are out to get him. We know what the Shikadi look like, but we've never seen their home planet (although I suspect it would involve a lot of transparency, which might be good for a modder who isn't a particularly great artist [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] )

So my point is that connecting the mod to the existing Keen games with both the storyline and the location/characters makes it more interesting for me.

title: re:
content:
That's pretty much what the Keen Community Mod was supposed to be... Keen revisited the Shadowlands. Well, technically, he visited them for the first time, since it was a prequel. Although, even more technically, he wasn't in the same area of the Shadowlands... he was going to be further east. In episode 2, he would have been underground, and in episode 3, he would have reached the Gnosticene capital. It was also going to explain why the Gnosticenes owed Keen a favour.

But alas, it never happened [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]

title: Re: re:
content:
Check the following:
Tools > Options > Content > Load Images > for the originating web site only

The "load images" should be checked, the "for the orig..." should not be.
(I could link to an image on my server, and using for instance PHP, track who is viewing it, from which site, how often, and things like that.
This is often (ab)used in e-mails, especially by spammers wanting to know if their mails are actually opened or not.)

Edit: Speaking of technical problems, is anyone else having difficulties using the masthead/banner PCKF image to return to the forum index?
It's linking to "hhttp://", obviously an unknown protocol, but it seems to be working just fine on other forums here...Retodon8

title: Re: New mod idea!
content: Well this topic failed miserably. Oh, well. Hopefully this sub-forum will find some good use, but it doesn't look like it's gonna happen any time soon.

title: Re: Lies! Unfailed! This Sub-Forum Begins Here!
content:
[hr]Apocalypse [UNFAILED!]
[hr]Not quite. This section of the forum is meant to be about Keen Modding--using the original Commander Keen games to create new adventures. Mainly what this thread attempted to do was establish some sort of demand indicator, so we modders can better tune our creations to the tastes of our audience.

What you're talking about here is Quake/Doom modding. A Keen game using one of these engines would certainly be impressive, and I wish you all the luck with it. However, keep discussion about that project to Unofficial Keen Games.

[hr]Apocalypse >Commander keen with a flamethrower[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]
[hr]This can certainly be done, and indeed will eventually. Levellord created a laser in one of her mods... either a Patchwork, Generic or Cooperative... she's made so many, so I don't recall which it is. The concept can easily be tweaked to incorporate a flamethrower.

[hr]Apocalypse >Quality
>Good story
>new stuff
[hr]Easier said than done. The point here is, what exactly would you consider a quality production? What would you consider a good story? In fact, what would you consider a bad story? What sort of new stuff would you like to see? What little things in existing mods, or in the original games, were you particularly impressed by and would like to see more of?

That's the sort of information we're seeking here, with the hope that the more feedback we get the more enjoyable we can make our mods.

title: Alright
content:
Thanks for making a valiant effort, Spleen. You're the best.

Apocalypse Gohan, let's get a few things straight here. This thread was asking what you'd like to see in a mod, and how mods can be made more interesting to the general non-modding community. You responded to this prompt by posting picture after picture of edited sprites, without any real contribution to the topic. Keen with a sprite from Keen4 sticking out the nozzle of his gun does absolutely nothing to help a mod be made. Especially not if item number two on your checklist is "quality."

Give me one 'quality' reason why Keen should arm himself with a flamethrower. One. It's already been established in this thread that PLOT is relevant to the interest in a mod; if we just say "Hay guyz Keen hav f;lamz now kewl lol!" nobody (except maybe you) is going to download and play it.

Second, as Spleen pointed out, this forum is about KeenModding, using the Keen games' engine to create new games, possibly about Keen. If you're looking for QuakeMods, or DoomMods, or any other types of mods BESIDES KeenMods, you should look into another forum.

Third, what're you doing posting cut-paste'd screenshots of Mario 3, Keen, and Link? How does that contribute to discussion of modding, at all? Were you expecting people to somehow rally to your side, singing your praise for spending 10 minutes with MS Paint to combine graphics from a few different games?

... Why did we even bother making a "Modding" subsection of the PCKF, anyway? If this is the most use it's going to get, this whole thing should be wiped. I'll stick with K:M.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/posted-pics/XkyRauhKeenLogo.png[/img]

Sorry, very sorry.

Quality... (official nintendo seal of quality...heh.)

It means just that, crappy and unplayable mods suck and making quality mods matter the most.

Quality can refer to

a. a specific characteristic of an object (the qualities of ice - i.e. its properties).

b. the achievement or excellence of an object (good quality ice - i.e. not of inferior grade).

c. the essence of an object (the quality of ice - i.e. "iceness").

d. the meaning of excellence itself.

The first meaning is technical, the second practical, the third artistic and the fourth metaphysical. All four meanings, and therefore the meaning of quality, are synonymous with good.

Philosophy and common sense tend to see quality as related either to subjective feelings or to objective facts. The subject-object in question might be a concrete and functional (e.g. Arisotelian) value to be learnt and applied (a and b), or a psychic (e.g. platonic) ideal to be apprehended and represented (c). A third view tends to see quality not as a secondary value that something has, rather a primary truth which comprises apparent subjects and objects (d).

So the quality of something depends on the criteria being applied to it. Something might be good because it is useful, because it is beautiful, or simply because it exists. Determining or finding quality therefore involves an understanding of use, beauty and existence - what is useful, what is beautiful and what exists.

title: Interesting.
content: We didn't request that you modify your posts, but your efforts to realign this topic are indeed appreciated.

title: Re: Interesting.
content:
* What do you want to see in a mod?

1. Level design, and hopefully not too easy
2. good patches, they make the game much more interesting
3. graphics, and NOT recolored or ripped
4. a good storyline, not essential, but makes the game much better if there is
5. suprises, MM and the end of K3 is agood example, as is the end of 5 and 6


* What seperates a mod from a fangame, to you?

1. creativity- fangames can do things that mods can't, but mods can have that keen to them whereas fangames hardly ever do
2. The continued use of the keen engine
3. The fact that 2,3,5,6 mods can only be propely used by other keen fans and not just anyone who stumbles across it [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-mortlol.gif[/img]
4. the ideas - an idea for a creature for a mod need to be fit into an existing sprite or patch, but for a fangame it can be adapted to a wider range
5. fangames can use complicated puzzles to their advantage, but most keen fans already know about the teleported and falling block, so most mod ingame puzzles need careful thought.


* Why do you prefer one over the other?

1. mods have that keen feel to them- this is difficult to duplicate in a fangame
2. the amazement when a particularly good patch is used
3. knowing that 16 color art is harder than 256 color art, which is a good challenge
4. the levels in mods - the restrictions of tiles mean that you need to be careful, but you can still create good levels. Good levels make a lot of a mod in my opinion
5. the knowledge that other keen fans know the game, and the challenge to make it a game which doesn't give everything away (ie if someone sees something bouncing along they think oh its a yorp replacement whereas a patched yorp may look like something new)


* What can mods do to attract your attention?

1. level design
2. graphics
3. patches
4. storyline
5. suprises

[hr]

---Freeyorp

I would like to modify the game so if you die in a level, you lose the lives, points, and ammunition you gained in it.

I never liked how you kept all that stuff. You can hoard points that way, and it makes finding the secret areas with high-value items less meaningful, because you can get a higher score by just dying over and over and grabbing mundane stuff.
